Award.AwardTitle: Quantum chemical methods for studying photoinitiated processes in biological systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Spiridoula Matsika of Temple University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry division to develop and use theoretical models to understand photo-initiated phenomena in biological systems. Matsika and her research group develop efficient quantum chemical methods for excited states and conical intersections, which are essential in studying photo-initiated processes. The proposed methods enhance the efficiency of multireference configuration interaction (MRCI) by using natural orbitals obtained from a high multiplicity state instead of the traditional multi-configurational orbitals. Initial results show that this approach reduces the computational cost significantly compared to traditional MRCI without loss of accuracy. Gradients are also being developed for this method. The effect of the environment is taken into account by a hybrid quantum mechanics/ molecular mechanics (QM/MM) method. When developed, the developed methods will be used to study photophysical and photochemical events in pi-stacked nucleobases. This work contributes to our understanding of how DNA interacts with UV radiation.

Photo-initiated processes, a primary focus of this work, play an important role in photosynthesis, vision, and photochemical damage and repair in DNA. Matsika's research is very useful in studying photo-initiated processes in biological systems. The methodology will be implemented in publicly available computational software. Students from groups that are under-represented in the physical sciences and undergraduate students are an integral part of the PI's research team.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit
Computational chemistry has become an important part of chemical research with  many chemists using computational tools to understand their findings or to predict  new  directions. For many problems, especially those involving the ground state of  molecules and thermal reactions,  computational methods have become  very efficient and can be used  routinely. In  photochemistry and photophysics, however the  advancement is slower. The  methods developed during this project contribute to a better treatment  and understanding of  processes initiated by light which produces excited molecules. An important outcome of this project has been the development of an efficient approach to study excited states involved in photochemistry and photophysics of molecular systems. By modifying a traditional approach we were able to gain a speedup of 1-2 orders of magnitude.  
The interaction of UV radiation with DNA can lead to photochemical damage, so it is very important to understand this interaction at the molecular level. This may provide insight into the protection from DNA damage, as well as developing artificial bases. Our work during this project has contributed significantly to understanding the competing pathways that can quench the dangerous photochemical reactions. We have found efficient photophysical pathways that dissipate the energy absorbed preventing reactions. We have also found how neighboring bases can quench the production of the most common photochemical product, a thymine dimer, by diverting the charge distribution that could lead to the reaction.  Finally, we have  learned a lot about bases which are similar to the natural bases in DNA and RNA, but they have very different properties. These differences can be used to develop fluorescent  probes which could be used in biological studies. 


Broader Impacts
A primary goal in our group is to  integrate the research activities with the training and development of students. Two graduate students and two postdoctoral fellows have participated in research under the current NSF grant. They are trained in high level electronic structure methods, nuclear dynamics, QM/MM methods, nonadiabatic events and applications to photophysics of biological molecules.  One of the most successful aspects of our group has been to guide undergraduate students in research.  Eight papers have been published in well recognized journals in the field  as a result of  research performed by  undergraduate  students in my group, with three of these papers published during the current support period. In all of these papers, except one,  the students were first authors in the corresponding manuscripts, which is quite uncommon for undergraduate students.   Many of these students have continued their successful career after their graduation from Temple, and they are in graduate schools at the University of Pennsylvania, Caltech, University of Chicago and University of Colorado at Boulder. 
Encouraging underrepresented students to follow careers in STEM fields has to start before college.  With this goal in mind, the PI has participated as a workshop leader in a conference organized by  students at Swarthmore College, where  middle school-aged girls are invited to Swarthmore's campus for a series of hands-on workshops in the natural sciences, math, and engineering.
